definitions.def: Add exponents when powers with same base are multiplied: <flashml width="100.5" height="24.75" color="33CCCC">  <math>    <mrow>      <msup>        <mi>x</mi>        <mi>a</mi>      </msup>      <mo>·</mo>      <msup>        <mi>x</mi>        <mi>b</mi>      </msup>      <mo>=</mo>      <msup>        <mi>x</mi>        <mrow>          <mi>a</mi>          <mo>+</mo>          <mi>b</mi>        </mrow>      </msup>    </mrow>  </math></flashml>

Subtract exponents when powers with same base are divided: <flashml width="107.25" height="24.75" color="33CCCC">  <math>    <mrow>      <msup>        <mi>x</mi>        <mi>a</mi>      </msup>      <mo>÷</mo>      <msup>        <mi>x</mi>        <mi>b</mi>      </msup>      <mo>=</mo>      <msup>        <mi>x</mi>        <mrow>          <mi>a</mi>          <mo>−</mo>          <mi>b</mi>        </mrow>      </msup>    </mrow>  </math></flashml>

secText: In this section, we discuss the rules for multiplying and dividing powers. The base of the powers being multiplied or divided must be the same.

To multiply two powers with the same base, you add the exponents.  For example,   when you multiply 2<sup class="">3 </sup>by 2<sup class="">2</sup>, you add the exponents 3 and 2 to get 5. The product is 2<sup class="">5</sup>.
To divide powers, you subtract the exponents. For example, when dividing x7 by x4, you subtract 4 from 7 to get 3. The quotient is x3.
